thread.title: Auckland Nines 2017: Canterbury Bulldogs Josh Reynolds defends day one no-show after NRL threatened fine | The Courier-Mail
thread.title_full: Auckland Nines 2017: Canterbury Bulldogs Josh Reynolds defends day one no-show after NRL threatened fine | The Courier-Mail

title: Auckland Nines 2017: Canterbury Bulldogs Josh Reynolds defends day one no-show after NRL threatened fine | The Courier-Mail
text:
Auckland Nines 2017: Bulldogs Josh Reynolds defends day one no-show after NRL threatened fine AAP with Staff Writers, FOX SPORTS February 5, 2017 1:14pm 
CANTERBURY star Josh Reynolds has defended the club’s decision not to play both him and David Klemmer on day one of the NRL Auckland Nines. 
The NRL had reportedly threatened to dock the Bulldogs their $110,000 appearance fee at the tournament if the star pairing were again benched. 
After crashing out of finals contention with two group losses on Saturday, Nines captain Reynolds and Klemmer finally made their first appearance in a dead rubber on Sunday. 
But their return failed to prevent the Bulldogs crashing to a 28-4 loss to Cronulla, with Reynolds later explaining why he was a scratching the day prior. 
“I think it’s a good opportunity for the young guys to have a game. We’re obviously going to play in the NRL week to week and the young guys, sometimes it’s hard for them,” Reynolds told AAP. Ponga excites Knights fans 0:45 
NRL: Newcastle fans have a lot to look forward to after a great showing for the Cowboys in their first game at the Auckland Nines. February 4th 2017 /video/video.news.com.au/Sport/NRL/ Ponga excites Knights fans 
“I’ve played premier league, you don’t really get to show yourself sometimes because you’re playing at the park or whatever. I don’t necessarily think it’s a bad thing. 
“I know where the fans are coming from in some ways. You don’t want to lose in any game. But Des is the boss and whatever he says goes.” 
Hasler’s contempt for the Nines has been made clear over the tournament’s four-year existence, with the big name coach never travelling to the event and regularly sending understrength squads. 
Under NRL rules clubs must name one of their top five earners and 12 of their top 25 first grade squad for the Nines, but both Klemmer and Reynolds watched the entire first day’s play from the sidelines.
